header.title: "Out-of-Body Experiences" (OBEs) and Brain Localisation. A Perspective

central_thesis: The paper critically evaluates the reductionist claim that Out-of-Body Experiences (OBEs) are fully explained by stimulating a specific brain area. Neppe argues that such conclusions are premature and unwarranted, emphasizing that electrically induced OBEs are atypical compared to spontaneous subjective paranormal experiences (SPE-OBEs), that single-case pathological findings cannot be generalized, and that the complex nature of OBEs necessitates further research into potential subtypes and exogenous factors beyond mere neurological causality, without confirming or denying their veridicality.

structure_content.summary: Critiques Blanke et al.'s findings on electrically induced OBEs, highlighting limitations in generalizing from a single patient with specific pathology, questioning the nature of the induced experience, and emphasizing that such findings do not confirm or deny the veridicality of broader subjective paranormal experiences.

Addresses the sensational media portrayal of Blanke et al.'s cautious scientific findings, which suggested a brain region for illusory body perceptions, contrasting it with the author's extensive work on subjective paranormal experiences and the brain.

Defines 'Out-of-Body Experiences' (OBEs) and introduces 'Subjective Paranormal (Psi) Experience' (SPEs) as a broader category for subjective experiences, allowing for analysis of brain function in relation to both normal and paranormal subjective phenomena.

Details the experimental context of Blanke et al.'s study, involving brain stimulation in a single epilepsy patient under local anesthesia, and notes the preliminary nature of findings based on a sole case.

Presents the specific, limited, and transitory 'out-of-body' and body-transformation sensations experienced by the patient upon angular gyrus stimulation, noting their atypical nature compared to spontaneous SPE OBEs which typically involve seeing the whole body and surroundings without distortion.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Actual Conclusions Made in the Blanke et al. Paper
structure_content.summary: Highlights Blanke et al.'s own cautious interpretation, suggesting visual attention changes and/or current amplitude as explanations, contrasting this with the media's oversimplified attribution of OBEs solely to angular gyrus stimulation.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Angular Gyrus and Localization of OBEs
structure_content.summary: Explores the known functions of the right angular gyrus in spatial relations and attention, providing a theoretical link to body perception. It then presents an older, contradictory case of an OBE induced in a temporal lobe epileptic patient, suggesting non-localization or multiple localities for OBE induction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Comparisons: Difficulty localising symptomatology in déjà vu and memory
structure_content.summary: Argues that similar to déjà vu and memory, which lack single, consistent brain localizations despite stimulation-induced experiences, OBEs may also prove to be non-localizable, even if purely endogenous.

structure_content.chapter_title: Comparisons: Different subcategories of déjà vu
structure_content.summary: Discusses the existence of at least four phenomenologically distinct subtypes of déjà vu, each with potentially different etiologies, and suggests a similar need for detailed subcategorization research for OBEs to avoid oversimplified conclusions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Temporal lobe symptomatology, olfactory hallucinations and subjective paranormal symptomatology
structure_content.summary: Explores links between temporal lobe functioning and various SPEs, including olfactory hallucinations, noting that while anomalous brain function may be associated, it neither confirms nor denies the veridicality of SPEs, which could originate endogenously or from an external reality.

Defines the 'reductionistic fallacy' as the oversimplification of complex phenomena to purely physical explanations, critiquing its application to OBEs where intricate subjective experiences are reduced to mere brain stimulation.

Summarizes the paper's main conclusions: the stimulated OBE is atypical; generalization from a single, pathological case is unwarranted; causal links require more extensive research with normal subjects; OBEs are likely non-localizable; multiple brain areas may be involved; and brain function patterns neither confirm nor deny the objective reality of SPEs.

key_concepts.definition: A curious, usually brief sensation in which a person's consciousness seems to become detached from the body and take up a remote viewing position (as defined by Grusser & Landis, 1991; Hecaen & Ajuriaguerra, 1952, and used by Blanke et al.).

A term developed by Neppe to emphasize that subjective experiences, including OBEs, need not be objectively demonstrated in a lab but can be analyzed for links to normal or abnormal brain functioning without confirming or denying their veridicality.

The implicit assumption that complex phenomena are 'nothing but' their physical components or brain processes, leading to oversimplified explanations that ignore higher-level complexities or potential non-physical aspects.

A brain region in the parietal lobe, particularly the right angular gyrus, known to coordinate spatial relations and attention shifts, which Blanke et al. implicated in the generation of 'illusory own-body perceptions' or OBEs when electrically stimulated.

A range of symptoms or experiences associated with the temporal lobe, including some forms of déjà vu, olfactory hallucinations, and various subjective paranormal experiences (SPEs), suggesting its involvement in mediating such phenomena.

practical_system.description: This paper is an academic commentary and critical analysis of a scientific study on Out-of-Body Experiences (OBEs); it does not describe a practical system, ritual, or magical method for achieving or inducing OBEs. Instead, it critically evaluates the limitations of a neuroscientific explanation for such phenomena.

relevant_quotes.text: OBEs and complex somatosensory illusions can be artificially induced by electrical stimulation of the cortex," and that their "anatomical selectivity suggest that they have a common origin in body-related processing, supported by the restriction of these visual experiences to the patient's own body. During her OBE, the patient only 'saw' that part of her body that she also felt was modified during her body-transformation experiences.

In my opinion, these descriptions appear atypical for the SPE OBE that is seen in SP Experients. When they are elevated above the body, they see not only their own body but the surroundings, and reports of body distortions do not play a role. Moreover, they are generally not transitory in that they are maintained if the subject attempts an "examination."

The reductionistic fallacy is common in science, medical science and psychology. It implies implicit "nothing but" in front of some physical relation, with an assumed purely physical hierarchy of sciences.

Even though a certain pattern of brain function, either as a trait or state condition, may allow the experience of anomalous events, this would neither confirm nor deny the veridicality of any kind of SPE, including the OBE, as deriving either from outside the brain, or endogenously—when the SPEs would be artifactual dysfunctions in the brain akin to hallucinations.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is highly relevant to Esotericism and Occultism as it directly addresses the scientific 'explanation' of Out-of-Body Experiences (OBEs), a phenomenon frequently reported in esoteric traditions and magical practices (e.g., astral projection, remote viewing). It critically dissects reductionist attempts to categorize such subjective experiences solely as brain dysfunctions, thereby defending the potential for alternative interpretations, including those aligned with an 'outside, usually covert, reality' – a concept central to many occult philosophies. By emphasizing the atypicality of induced OBEs versus spontaneous ones and the need for rigorous subcategorization, it reinforces the complexity of these experiences beyond simple neurological causality.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academics in parapsychology, neuropsychiatry, philosophy of mind, and anyone interested in the scientific study of consciousness and subjective anomalous experiences. It is particularly valuable for practitioners and theorists of Esotericism and Occultism who grapple with the interface between scientific materialism and spiritual/magical phenomena, offering a sophisticated argument against oversimplified neurological explanations of complex subjective states.
